abstract: Sen. Barack Obama may have earned record-breaking ratings for his acceptance speech on Thursday, the final night of the Democratic National Convention, but network television attracted otherwise tiny audiences during prime time. According to Nielsen’s final ratings, CBS led the night with “Big Brother,” which drew 6 million viewers at 8 p.m., the night’s largest audience prior to the 10 p.m. convention coverage. CBS broadcast a rerun of “CSI” at 9 p.m. (5.3 million). Fox ranked runner up on the night with two special episodes of its honesty-testing game show “The Moment of Truth” at 8 p.m. (3.7 million) and 9 p.m. (5.2 million). ABC broadcast reruns of its regular Thursday night shows, “Ugly Betty” (3.1 million) and “Grey’s Anatomy” (4 million), at 8 and 9 p.m., respectively. Meanwhile, NBC struggled in a distant fourth place with pre-season football coverage of the Jacksonville Jaguars’ victory over the Washington Redskins, which averaged 2.8 million viewers from 8 to 9:53 p.m.

lead_paragraph: Sen. Barack Obama may have earned record-breaking ratings for his acceptance speech on Thursday, the final night of the Democratic National Convention, but network television attracted otherwise tiny audiences during prime time.

headline.main: Ratings: Barack Obama, and All the Rest
